column4: Got problem choosing installer. i will run lamp on this computer but will also use it as a desktop... so wich installer should i choose then? :S
it doesn't really matter, you can always install packages later.
!lamp > ITS_FOR_REAL    (ITS_FOR_REAL, see the private message from Ubotu)
yeah sure i know that... just curious what i will miss fresh out of the box in both cases ;)
have they cut down on media progs in server version? etc
do they both got simliar x?

if you use the desktop CD, you will have the ubuntu-desktop package installed. same if you use alternate/minimal and install the desktop version. otherwise, you'll only have ubuntu-standard and/or ubuntu-minimal installed.
the server version comes with no X at all.
!server
thats the answer i was looking for....  need x to go with.. or it will help anyway! thx alot

but it does by no means mean that you can't install X later... it's a matter of doing "sudo apt-get install thedesktopyouwant", really. if you're unsure, use the minimal CD, that's only an 8 megs download, and it'll get the rest (whatever you tell it to get) off the net
!shortcuts > LNX1    (LNX1, see the private message from Ubotu)
yeah sure i "know" but i got answer what i was looking for! thx alot

since i will use it as a desktop with irc msn xmms etc etc it will prob be easier and faster to go with desktop. then install lamp. thats what i did last i tried and it worked out nice. just wondered if it was any huge bennefit going for server version instead but it doesnt sound so for me
the server version comes with a tweaked kernel, that's all. but then if you're going to do desktop stuff, you don't want the tweaked kernel.
yeah great
and note that when i say "server version" i don't mean the "server" option in the alternate or minimal CDs, because they're two different things
hehe yeah!!
im stupid... but not that...
:D
it never seemed very obvious to me that there was a difference.
hehe yeah ok. whats obvious to one... might not be obvious to another so its always good to tell it all ;)
